message.content:
We can “back‐out” the taxes payable by noticing that in the opening (“Initial”) entries no tax is recorded so the opening balance of the tax payable account is zero. Then, whenever a sale is recorded the system “collects” a tax amount – many sales rows come with a “tax_amount” value. In our work the purchases (and expenses, etc.) do not have an entered tax amount and so do not “credit” the tax payable account. (In a real system the business would offset its output VAT with input credit, but here the only “tax_amount” figures appear in the sale‐transactions.) 

Thus to compute the “final tax payable” we sum the tax amounts from every transaction of type “Sale”. (In our table the “Sale” rows are the ones whose id begins with “Sale”.)

Step–by–step we inspect each “Sale” row and add its tax_amount value:

If we add up every one of these numbers the total comes to approximately 38,779.91 (all figures in the same monetary unit rounded to two‐decimals).

Since no “initial tax payable” entry exists (the “Initial” entries do not include any tax component) the beginning balance is zero.

Thus, the final “taxes payable” (the net tax the business “owes” from its sales because no purchase credit is shown) is 38,779.91.

So our answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Taxes Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Taxes Payable End Value": "38779.91"
  }
}
